To be clear, the `_password` attribute of `PasswordUser` is a non-public attribute by convention, as its name begins with a single underscore.

`_password` is intended to be used in the public `@property`-decorated getter/setter methods that implement the `password` instance attribute. The implementation of the setter method doesn't follow convention, however, and although it worked anyway with SQLAlchemy < 1.1.15, it no longer does with SQLAlchemy 1.2.0. Because the SQLAlchemy version requirement in the latest release of Airflow just grabs the most recent release, the `password` setter method will not work in environments where Airflow was installed after 2017-12-27 (when SQLAlchemy 1.2.0 was release) unless the SQLAlchemy requirement is overridden or an older version has been otherwise installed.

#2955 fixes the setter method that no longer works in SQLAlchemy 1.2, but there are other conflicts between the latest release of flask-admin and SQLAlchemy 1.2 that cause some failures in Airflow's test suite. https://github.com/flask-admin/flask-admin/pull/1586 (which has been merged) will hopefully resolve the other failures with #2955, but not until there's a new release of flask-admin, and it's been over a year now since that project's latest release... :pensive: 

In the meanwhile, though, https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/commit/5e4d7d8d7da250cacc15d8a2247098f0b42a3def pins `sqlalchemy>=1.1.15,<1.2.0`, so whenever it gets into a new Airflow release, the problematic setter method should stop being broken, and we won't have to tell users that they need to modify a non-public attribute.

So, since we've got a fix in place for incompatibilities with 1.2.0 on master and a PR to fix this particular problem once other dependency conflicts with 1.2.0 are resolved, should this PR be closed?

Talked to our internal dataflow contact, the [dataflow.projects.jobs.list ](https://cloud.google.com/dataflow/docs/reference/rest/v1b3/projects.jobs/list) was the pre-localization URL when dataflow was only available in us-central1. Given that dataflow now supports multiple locations, one could either use [dataflow.projects.locations.jobs.list](https://cloud.google.com/dataflow/docs/reference/rest/v1b3/projects.locations.jobs/list) with a specific location or projects.jobs.aggregated which lists jobs in all locations. To make things easier, we should probably use the latter.

@jgao54   Passing all the env variables is kind of the point.  For some environments, you need things like path, pythonpath, virtualenv stuff, who knows what other env variables are used by the operator.  Credentials/secrets, etc.

I think it's safe enough to assume that a subprocess can have the same environment as the parent process.
